ðŸªœ The AI Ladder

Now, hereâ€™s where Iâ€™d like to introduce you to a metaphor I typically use whenever people ask me how to break into the field: the AI Ladder.

ðŸªœ Instead of thinking of AI mastery as one big leap, imagine it as a ladder you climb.

Here are the 5 steps of the ladder I believe every aspiring ML / AI Engineer should climb:

  • Mathematical Foundations - The bedrock that makes everything else click.

  • Hands-on Practice - Frameworks, libraries, programming languages â€¦ actually putting theory into action.

  • Data Engineering - A good data foundation is everything. Without it, even the best models will crumble.

  • ML / AI Engineering - Learning the specifics about these two fields (ML pipelines, MLOps, LLMOps, finetuning, etc.)

  • Build, build, build - Projects are the real proof of mastery, so keep building!

Step 1 - Mathematical Foundations

Every strong ML engineer Iâ€™ve met has one thing in common: a rock-solid foundation in mathematics.

Why? Because math isnâ€™t just abstract theory here â€¦ itâ€™s the language of machine learning.

Linear algebra powers neural networks, probability and statistics help models make sense of uncertainty, and calculus is what drives optimization.

Without these tools, youâ€™ll constantly feel like youâ€™re standing on shaky ground.

Now, hereâ€™s the good news: building this foundation doesnâ€™t have to feel dry or overwhelming. It all comes down to how you prefer to learn.

ðŸ‘‰ If youâ€™re a visual learner who loves videos

Once youâ€™ve got the math down, itâ€™s time to roll up your sleeves and actually build things.

There are countless resources out there for learning frameworks and programming, but since I donâ€™t want this article turning into a library catalog ðŸ˜…, Iâ€™ll stick to one recommendation that I think gives you the biggest bang for your time:

ðŸ“˜ Machine Learning with PyTorch and Scikit-Learn by

Sebastian Raschka, PhD

Why this book?

Because it offers a detailed, hands-on walkthrough of the two most important frameworks for Machine Learning and Deep Learning (respectively): Scikit-Learn and PyTorch.

In my opinion, if you want to become a top ML Engineer, you absolutely need to feel at home with both of these libraries.

Step 3 - Data Engineering

Hereâ€™s the thing: without good data, even the most brilliant models fall apart.

Data really is the fuel of machine learning, and knowing how to handle it properly is a skill every aspiring ML Engineer needs.

This step is all about learning how to:

  • Collect and process raw data

  • Clean and transform it into usable formats

  • Store it efficiently

  • And pipeline it into your models

If you donâ€™t get this right, everything else suffers.

The good news? You donâ€™t have to become a full-fledged Data Engineer to succeed as an ML Engineer.

But you do need to be comfortable with the fundamentals.

When it comes to this step, my top recommendation is clear:

ðŸ“˜ Designing Data-Intensive Applications

Itâ€™s widely considered the gold standard for learning how to work with large-scale data systems. The book goes far beyond the basics, giving you both the mindset and the practical tools to design data pipelines, handle scalability and build reliable systems like a pro.

Step 4 - ML / AI Engineering

This is the step most people think of when they imagine â€œbecoming an ML / AI Engineerâ€.

Building and training models, experimenting with architectures, and solving real-world problems with machine learning.

But hereâ€™s the catch: itâ€™s not just about knowing how to fit a model.

Itâ€™s about understanding how to make that model robust, scalable, and deployable. That means going beyond notebooks and learning how to bring models into production.

At this stage, youâ€™ll want to focus on:

  • Model development and evaluation

  • Experiment tracking and reproducibility

  • MLOps fundamentals (deployment, monitoring, scaling)

  • Best practices for production-grade ML systems

My two recommendations here?

Designing Machine Learning Systems and AI Engineering, both by

Chip Huyen
.
